Rocky Intertidal 
Ecology

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Outline
1.
Zonation


✦
upper limit set by 
physical
 environment


✧
e.g., desiccation 


✦
lower limit set by 
biological
 interactions


✧
competition for space


✧
predation


2.
Species Diversity within a Rocky Intertidal Community


✦
intermediate disturbance


✦
keystone predator (Pisaster) 


3.
Trophic Cascade Effects

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Some 
Definitions

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Vertical Zonation:
The Hallmark of The Intertidal Zone
Communities are divided into distinct bands [zones] that are at characteristic heights in the intertidal
 
 


✧
Species are 
not
 randomly distributed throughout the intertidal zone, but rather are arranged within 
relatively narrow vertical ranges. 


✧
The zones look like sharply divided belts easily distinguished by the colors of the assemblage (i.e. 
community) of organisms that live there

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Physical Stresses:
1.
Desiccation


2.
Temperature


3.
Food Availability   


4.
Wave Energy


5.
Salinity


6.
Dissolved Oxygen
Stress Factors
Often Set The 
Upper Limit
 to Species Distributions

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Biological Factors
1.
Competition for Space
 
✦
note that space on a rock to attach is the 
valuable resource that is in short supply in 
the intertidal


2.
Predation
Biological Interactions:
Often Set The 
Lower Limit
 to Species 
Distributions

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Grey Barnacles
Rock Barnacles
The Cause of Zonation:
A Simple Barnacle Example
1.
The Upper Limit
 of both species (grey and rock barnacles) 
is determined by emersion; larvae that settle too high in the 
intertidal dry out and die (
physical factor
).  


✦
grey barnacles
 can tolerate drying better than 
rock 
barnacles
, so they settle higher in the intertidal.


2.
At
 
Lower Levels
, where the 
rock barnacles
 can survive, 
the rock barnacle out competes the little grey barnacle for 
space (
biological factor
) and this sets the lower limit for the 
little  grey barnacle.  


3.
The Lowest Limit
 of the adult 
rock barnacles
 is 
determined by competition from mussels, and predation by 
whelks or sea stars (
biological fac
tors).

© 2023 Bruce Monger
•
Upper Limit
 at which a species 
can occur in the intertidal is 
usually determined by 
physical 
factors
. 


•
Lower Limit
 is usually 
determined by 
biological factors
.
General Rule of 
Zonation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Control of Species Diversity within a Rocky 
Intertidal Community
1.
Intermediate Disturbance
2.
Keystone Predators

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Physical disturbance (e.g., wave energy from 
storms and log damage) can open up gaps or 
patches in the rocky intertidal.


2.
Intermediate Disturbance Hypothesis
 - 
disturbance maximizes species diversity by 
periodically removing competitively dominant 
species and allowing less competitive species to 
reestablish themselves


3.
Note: Too much disturbance keeps the rock bare 
with few species. Too little disturbance allows the 
dominant competitor for space to take over and 
form a monoculture (single species)
Physical Disturbance Can Regulate Species Diversity
 
Within a Community

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Mussels can out compete most of the other intertidal 
organisms for valuable space  
2.
Pisaster (Starfish) predation sets the lower distributional limit to 
mussels and  below this distributional limit other species can 
settle in 
3.
The removal of Pisaster allows mussels to take over 
and this leads 
to a decrease in the community’s species diversity (just mussels 
remain).
The 
Pisaster
 Starfish Sets Lower Limits of Mussel 
Distributions in Rocky Intertidal


Leads to Higher Species Diversity within a Rocky 
Intertidal Community
 
(Paine, 1966)
Starfish Predation Produces High  
Intertidal Community Diversity:

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Keystone Species:  
Species that have effects on their communities that are proportionately 
much greater than their abundance would suggest 
A rocky intertidal starfish 
called 
Pisaster
 is a 
classic type of keystone 
predator that strongly 
influences community 
diversity

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Tro p h i c   C a s c a d e :  
The Classic 
Sea Otter-Kelp Example
1. Sea Otters eat sea urchins
2. Sea urchins are herbivores that eat 
through the holdfast of kelp and 
dislodging them from the seafloor.
3. Removal of sea otters allows sea 
urchins to grow to high 
abundance 
4. Low abundance of sea otters leads to 
High abundance of sea urchins and 
Low abundance of kelp forests
©2004 Ken Ashman

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Massive Die-Off of Starfish 
Along the US West Coast 
2015-2016
See Also: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_I_B6U0GtI

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Tro p h i c   C a s c a d e :  
A
 
More Recent Example
, Sunflower Starfish-Kelp
1.
Sunflower starfish eat sea urchins
2.
Sea urchins are herbivores that eat kelp 
3.
Sunflower disease die-off removes predation on sea urchins. 
4.
Low
 
abundance of sunflower starfish from disease  leads to
 
high
 
abundance of sea urchins 
and 
low
 
abundance of kelp forests
https://www.npr.org/2021/03/31/975800880/in-hotter-climate-zombie-urchins-are-winning-and-kelp-forests-are-losing
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/04/dining/california-sea-urchin-kelp-coastline.html
https://www.nature.org/en-us/magazine/magazine-articles/kelp-forest/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.npr.org/2021/03/31/975800880/in-hotter-climate-zombie-urchins-are-winning-and-kelp-forests-are-losing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
In Parts of the Northern 
California Coast, 
95%
 of the 
Kelp Has Been Lost

© 2023 Bruce Monger

Zonation

upper limit set by 
physical
 environment


✦

 interactions


✧
competition

predation


2.

intermediate disturbance

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Coral Reefs

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Requirements for Coral Growth


2.
Human Impacts on Coral Reefs
Outline

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Requirements for Coral Growth
Section I

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Coral Anatomy
Calcium Carbonate Support Structure
NOTE: the process of building a calcium carbonate reef structure layer-by-layer 
is a very slow process: <1mm per year to about 20 mm per year

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Zooxanthellae
 are algal 
symbionts that live in the tissue of 
the coral polyp
Corals receive 60-90% of their 
overall nutrition from 
photosynthetic-derived products!!!
Coral Energetics

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Natural Limits to Coral Growth
1.
Temperature


2.
Sunlight


3.
Competition for Space


4.
Predation

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Temperature:
 Limits Most Coral Growth to Tropical Latitudes


✦
	
Optimal 26-28°C


✦
	
Restricted 18-36°C


Sunlight:
 
✦
Limits coral growth to a depth range extending from the ocean 
surface down to maximum of about 25 meters 


✦
Light required for zooxanthellae to photosynthesize

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/20_Grad_Isotherme.png/1024px-20_Grad_Isotherme.png
Boundary for 20°C Isotherm:   
Most corals live within this boundary.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Location of Coral Reefs

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/coral-reefs-15786954
Because corals rely heavily on 
the photosynthesis of 
Zooxanthellae, they have a 
depth limit, set by light levels, 
below which they cannot 
grow effectively - this limit is 
typically about 25 meters
The Depth Range Where 
Corals Can Grow is Set by 
Light Requirements

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Coral Reef Formation
1.
A new island forms
 (e.g., mantle hot spot or 
ocean-ocean plate collision) and a 
fringing reef 
develops in shallow sunlit waters close to shore of 
the island


2.
The island slowly sinks
 with age (crust cools and 
thins) and at the same time the coral 
slowly
 grows 
upward by secreting its calcium carbonate 
support structure layer-by-layer - this eventually 
forms a 
barrier reef
.


3.
Later in time the entire island is submerged and all 
that is left is the reef - referred to now as 
coral 
atoll.
fringing reef
barrier reef
new island
http://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/coral-reefs-15786954
coral atoll

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Drowned Coral Reefs
http://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/coral-reefs-15786954
If the island sinks too fast, or sea level rises too fast, the 
reef’s upward CaCO
3
 growth (mm yr
-1
) will not keep up and 
the coral will eventually stop growing because 
 
it becomes too submerged in deep/dark waters... 


These dead reefs are referred to as drowned reefs...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Corals Compete for Space: 
 
They Compete With Other Corals and With Macroalgae

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Corals Competing with Other Corals:   
Sweeper Tentacles

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Corals Competing with Other Corals:   
Sweeper Tentacles

© 2023 Bruce Monger
This starfish is a 
very
 important 
predator of corals


Can be the primary source of 
coral mortality in some cases
Predation by Crown 
of Thorns Starfish  
(
Acanthaster
)...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Human Impacts on Coral Reefs
Section II

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The competitive 
advantage for taking over 
space is shifted in favor of 
macroalgae when nutrients 
from agricultural activities 
run off the coast and onto 
coral reefs
Coral Competition with 
Macroalgae in High 
Nutrient Waters

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
This starfish is a 
very
 important predator 
of corals


✦
often the primary source of coral 
mortality 
2.
Eutrophic Conditions
 increase 
phytoplankton abundance that 
enhances the growth of 
Acanthaster
 
larvae
 (
meroplankton
) and this 
eventually leads to large increases in 
abundance of 
adults
 and subsequent 
high coral mortality
Predation by Crown of 
Thorns Starfish  
(
Acanthaster
)...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Coral Bleaching
1.
It is the zooxanthellae algae that give 
corals all of their beautiful natural colors


2.
Coral bleaching is the name given to an 
event where corals expel their symbiotic 
zooxanthellae algae due to environmental 
stress such as unusually warm water


3.
Corals can recover and regain their 
zooxanthellae if the stress is small or 
short-lived (a couple of weeks)


4.
Coral death follows if the stress is 
extreme
 and/or 
prolonged
.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Corals are extremely sensitive to increases 
in ocean temperature 
 
Just 1
º
C above normal temperatures for a period of a few weeks is 
enough to result in coral beaching.
http://www.globalcoralbleaching.org/#images

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Mass Bleaching Events
1.
Corals bleach when water rises 
1 
º
C 
above acclimated levels


2.
Global Average Temperature is now 
close to 1.1 
º
C above pre-industrial 
levels — and still rising... 


3.
Now, even small natural variability 
superimposed on this warming can now 
regularly raise local regions 1 
º
C above 
acclimated levels and cause coral 
bleaching.
Hoegh-Guldberg et al. 1999
Sea Surface Temperature
Projected Rise in Sea Surface Temperature Relative 
to Coral Bleaching Threshold (
blue line
)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The 2015-2016 El Nino Warming Effect, When Super-Imposed on the Multi-
Decadal Global Warming Trend, Was Disastrous for Coral Reefs!!
1997-1998
2015-2016
1981-1982
El Ninos are nothing new. They temporarily raise global 
average temperatures. However, when these temporary 
warming events are super imposed on the human-
caused multi-decadal warming they have increasingly 
devastating effects on coral reef mortality

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2018/08/explore-atlas-great-barrier-reef-coral-bleaching-map-climate-change/
Half 
of the Great Barrier 
Reef Was Bleached to 
Death Since 2016

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://e360.yale.edu/digest/great-barrier-reef-coral-cover-2022-record
In areas where coral cover expanded, it was 
mostly fast-growing Acropora corals
 
driving the growth. 


1.
Acropora are particularly vulnerable to strong waves 
generated by tropical cyclones.


2.
Acropora are highly susceptible to bleaching


3.
Acropora are the preferred target of crown-of-thorns 
starfish.


“
This means that large increases in hard 
coral cover can quickly be negated by 
disturbances on reefs where Acropora 
corals predominate,
”
 
A Word About Recent Reports of Coral 
Reef Increases on the Great Barrier Reef

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Oceanic Niño Index
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/september-2023-enso-outlook-el-nino-convo#:~:text=According to the September El,Index 
≥
 1.5  ̊Celsius).
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/september-2023-enso-outlook-el-nino-convo#:~:text=According to the September El,Index 
≥
 1.5  ̊Celsius).
There is now around a 71% 
chance that this event peaks 
as a strong El Niño this winter 
(Oceanic Niño Index 
≥
 1.5).

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Modeled onset of annual severe 
bleaching under 
Business as 
Usual
 emissions scenario
 
1.
Red regions will see regular beaching by 2030 
(
less than 15 years
)


2.
Orange and Yellow regions indicate onset of 
regular bleaching by 2040 (
about 25 years
)


3.
Blue regions have until 2050-2060 (
about 35 to 
45 years
)


4.
Note: COP-21 Pledges will add an additional 10 
years onto the onset dates above, but will not 
prevent severe annual bleaching from 
occurring...
van Hooidonk et al (2016), Nature, 6:39666, doi: 10.1038/srep39666

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Hoegh-Guldberg et al. (2007) Science Vol. 318.   pp. 1737 - 1742
1.
Increases in CO
2
 in the atmosphere 
leads to increases in ocean acidity


2.
Projected Increases in ocean acidity 
lead to slowing of calcium carbonate 
precipitation and/or eventually coral 
dissolution
Ocean Acidification
3.
An atmosphere above 480 ppm is 
Expected to Enhance Coral Loss - We 
are now at 417 ppm


4.
Note that Twice Pre-Industrial 
Atmospheric CO
2
 = 550 ppm

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Expected Scenario Of Reef Changes with Increasing Atmospheric CO
2
Hoegh-Guldberg et al. (2007) Science Vol. 318.   pp. 1737 - 1742
NOTE:  The atmospheric CO
2
 concentration is 
currently at 417 ppm 
and going up by
 
2-ppm to 3-ppm each year - 
so it will reach 450 in less than 
20 years
375 ppm
+1 
o
C
>500 ppm
> +3 
o
C
450-500 ppm
+2 
o
C

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Expected Scenario for Coral Reef Survival With 
1.5ºC Versus 2.0ºC Global Warming...
1. Coral reefs will decline by 
70-90%
 
in a 
1.5ºC world
 


2.
Virtually all (>99%)
 
coral reefs will be lost in a 
2ºC world
IPCC Special Report for Policy Makers on Global Warming of 1.5ºC 
Versus 2.0 ºC,  Published Oct 2018 
https://ipcc.ch/pdf/session48/pr_181008_P48_spm_en.pdf

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1. Coral reefs around the world are being degraded at an accelerated 
pace due to the combined effects of 
local-scale stressors
 caused by 
land-based pollution and by 
global-scale stressors
 due to a warming 
planet and increased ocean acidification.   


2. It is now widely recognized that local-scale stressors on coral reefs 
should be minimized 
as an immediate means of offsetting increases in 
global-scale stressors
.  


3.
Managing local water quality conditions
 
to alleviate the pressure 
from global-scale stresses is now a top reef management priority.
Overall: Coral Reefs Around The World Are In 
Rapid Decline

© 2023 Bruce Monger

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section I
Whale Evolution

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Pakicetus:
 
hoofed-mammal
 that is often classified as the earliest whale. It lived 
around 53 million years ago
 (
after the age of dinosaurs
). It looked rather like a 
dog/wolf with hoofed feet and long, thick tail. 


The shape of the ear region in the Pakicetus skull is highly unusual and only 
resembles the skulls of whales. The special ear bone feature is diagnostic for 
cetaceans and is found in no other species. 
https://www.amnh.org/explore/news-blogs/on-exhibit-posts/the-first-whale-pakicetus

© 2023 Bruce Monger
What did Pakicetus Really Look Like?
1. It had a skull that resembles a wolf or dog


2. It had an ankle bone that looks something like a deer’s leg (i.e., hoofed)
but some researchers 
wonder if a deer 
might not be a better 
possibility
Chinese Water Deer

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ambulocetus
 ("walking whale") was an early cetacean that could walk as 
well as swim. It lived during early Eocene some 49-50 million years ago. It 
is a transitional fossil that shows how whales evolved from land-living 
mammals.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Rodhocetus
 lived in the Middle Eocene 46-47 million years ago, and was 
still able to walk on land though not very well.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Dorudon
 lived during the Eocene about 36 to 40 million years ago. 
Dorudon reached about 5 meters in length and was a carnivore. The overall 
look of Dorudon was very similar to the modern whale. 
Dorudon lacked 
the ability to go on land.
 It had tiny hind legs that barely protruded from 
the body.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Basilosaurus
 lived at about the same time as Dorudon in the Eocene 
37 to 40 
million years ago. This creature had a pair of very small hind legs, about 2 feet 
long. Its jaw was around 5 feet long and was equipped with cone shaped teeth in 
the front and triangular shaped teeth in the back.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rspb.2021.1368

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Evolutionary Divergence of Baleen Whales From 
Toothed Whales
1.
All Baleen Whales (Mysticetes) are large filter-feeders 


2.
The exact means by which baleen are used differ among species:


✦
gulp-feeding


✦
skim-feeding


✦
bottom plowing 


3.
The first members appeared about 35 million years ago. These 
changes may have been a result of worldwide environmental 
change and physical changes in the oceans.

© 2023 Bruce Monger

Mysticetes


(Baleen)

(Toothed)

Odontocete (Toothed)

Baleen Whales (Mysticetes)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Baleen whales feed by gulping large 
quantities of seawater and then 
squeezing the water through the 
baleen “filter” to retain copepods, 
krill and small fish.

Whale Seasonal Migration

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Pacific Humpback Migration
Summer:
  Feeding at      
high latitudes with long   
day length and lots of 
biological productivity


Winter:
  Calving at low 
latitudes - usually warm, 
but low or no food

© 2023 Bruce Monger

Section IV
1.
Vocalization in Whales


2.
Anthropogenic Noise Pollution

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Vocalization In Whales
Odontocetes (toothed whales)
 
✦
Produce rapid bursts of clicks and whistles
 
✦
Single clicks are generally used for echolocation 


✦
Collections of clicks and whistles are used for close 
communication.
Mysticetes (baleen whales) 
 
✦
Often make the long, low-frequency, sounds known as the     
whale song.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
The complex and haunting sounds of the Humpback Whale (and some Blue 
Whales) are believed to be 
primarily used in sexual selection
 during mating 
season, but the simpler sounds of other whales have a year-round use. 


2.
Given the poor visibility of aquatic environments, and the fact that sound travels 
so well in water, simple sounds 
may play a role in navigation (i.e., echo 
location).
 For instance, the depth of water or the existence of a large 
obstruction ahead may be detected by loud low frequency noises made by 
baleen whales. 


3.
While many toothed whales are capable of using echolocation to detect the 
size and nature of objects (e.g., prey), 
this capability has never been 
demonstrated in baleen whales.
Mysticete Vocalization

Frequency

Ambient Ship Noise
No Boat Traffic

 Christopher Clark (Cornell Lab of Ornithology)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
“Acoustic Habitat” 
is no different than spatial habitat and 
must be preserved.


2.
“Noise Pollution”
 is every bit as destructive as other forms of  
more familiar marine pollution (oil, nitrogen, plastic)
Dr. Christopher Clark Cornell Lab of Ornithology...
Noise Pollution...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
PCB Poisoning of Killer Whales 
Modern Whaling
Section V

© 2023 Bruce Monger
PCB Poisoning of Killer Whales

© 2023 Bruce Monger
PCB Pollution in Orca Whales...
PCB = Long-Lived Polychlorinated Biphenyls 
1.
Banned in the 70’s, and declined after that, but still remain relatively high in the 
environment


2.
Bioaccumulates to high concentration in the fat of top predator species.  
 
3.
Northern hemisphere Orcas among the most heavily contaminated animals on 
earth. 


4.
Passed from mother to calf in her milk.


5.
Predictions are that half of Orca whales might be lost within 30 to 50 years
 
6.
80% of global PCB stockpiles have not been properly destroyed
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/environment/2018/09/orcas-killer-whales-poisoned-pcbs-pollution/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Modern Whaling...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Question...
Which of the following animals would you 
least
 want to eat?
(a)
Cow


(b)
Pig


(c)
Cat


(d)
Dog


(e)
Whale

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Modern-Day Whaling
An international convention on whaling culminated in the signing of the 
International 
Convention for the Regulation of Whaling (ICRW)
 in 1946


✦
The aim was to:  "provide for the proper conservation of whale stocks and  thus 
make possible the commercial whaling and the orderly development of the whaling 
industry".


The 
International Whaling Commission (IWC)
 was set up under the terms of the ICRW 
to 
make decisions on quota levels based on the findings from the Scientific 
Committee of the IWC.
 Countries which are not members of IWC are not bound by its 
regulations and conduct their own management programs.


The members of the IWC voted on 23 July 1982 to apply a moratorium to all 
commercial whaling beginning in 1985...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Current Whaling Efforts...
In spite of the ban, Japan, Norway and Iceland have found ways 
to continue to hunt whales...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Japan
 Until fairly recently, Japan whaled 
by [falsely] claiming its whaling operation was for scientific 
purposes.
 The IWC allows lethal scientific whaling, but only when it addresses questions vital to 
management. Numbers varied each year, but on average it was close to 1,000 Minke (not-endangered), 50 Fin 
(endangered), 50 Humpback (endangered) and 5 Sperm (endangered) whales each year. 


Norway
 
registered an objection/reservation
 when the 1982 IWC whaling moratorium was signed, and was 
thus not bound by it. In 1993 Norway decided to exercise its reservation against the moratorium and resumed 
domestic commercial whaling. 
They now take Minke (not-endangered) whales. 


Iceland
 issued licenses in October 2006 for a commercial whale hunt in addition to its continuing hunt for 
scientific purposes. 
Iceland has an exemption to the moratorium through the reservation it made in 
2002.
 They take Minke (not-endangered) whales each year.   They stopped taking fin whales (endangered) in 
2023.

Japanese Whaling: A Chronology of Events... 
✦
The International Whaling Commission’s Scientific Committee ruled many times that the 
research Japan said it was conducting did not require hunting. Japan continued to hunt anyway.


✦
2014
 The International Court in Hague ruled that Japan was in violation of the moratorium and 
that the science loophole they were using was not valid


✦
Japan at first said it would abide by the International Court’s ruling, but later said it would not 
abide by the ruling and would resume its whale hunting


✦
In 
2018
 Japan asked the International Whaling Commission to allow whaling with set quotas, 
but the request was denied.


✦
 
2019 
Japan formally withdrew from the International Whaling Convention and resumed 
commercial whaling in its own territorial waters and EEZ.
  
✦
Japan will now allow the hunting of three species: minke, Bryde's and sei whales (
sei whales 
are endangered
).
